content:
Welcome, you are participating in a negotiation game. You are playing as the agent named Bob. The other agent with whom you are playing is named Alice. In this game, two agents bargain over how to divide items over multiple rounds. The number of rounds is incredibly high. Each agent only knows their own item values. Each item has different values for each agent. Each agent submits their own proposal for how to divide the items.


Your messages must be sent in this exact format:
<message>
your-message-here
</message>
There must be no extraneous text outside the tags. They should be concise - less than 400 characters. Finalization is not allowed in messages.


Your finalizations must be sent in this exact format:
<finalize>
{  "Bob": {    "coins": x  },  "Alice": {    "coins": y  }}
</finalize>
There must be no extraneous text outside the tags. Your proposal should be consistent with itself - the sum of items that you propose for yourself and the items that you propose for the other agent should equal the total available items.


Each round is played as follows:
0) Random values for each items are generated for each agent.
1) One agent is designated as the starting agent
2) The starting agent sends a message
3) The second agent sends a message
4) The starting agent sends a finalization
5) The second agent sends a finalization

Each agent can only send 1 message per round.
The starting agent alternates each round.

Each agent only knows the values of items from their own perspective. You cannot see the other agent's item values unless they explicitly share this information in their messages. And vice versa. You are strongly encouraged to use your messages to discuss item values with the other agent.

The items obtained by each agent at the end of a round are proportional to the number of items they proposed for themselves in their finalization. First example: If both players propose to take all the items, they both get half. Second example: If one agent proposes to take all the items and the other agent proposes to take none, the first agent gets all the items and the second agent gets nothing.

Your round points are calculated by multiplying the number of each item you get by how much you value that item. For example, if you get 7 coins and you value each coin at 5 points, you'll earn 35 points for the round.

The distribution for the values are independent across rounds. The samples are different for both agents, but the distribution is the same.


Your goal is to maximize the sum of the points you will accumulate over the course of the game, not the points of a single round.


Before the game starts, you must think and strategize. The other player will adapt its strategy with respect to yours. You must find the optimal non-exploitable strategy. In order to strategize, you must use the format:
<strategize>
Your thoughts and strategy here..
</strategize>
There must be no extraneous text outside the tags. You should think inside the tags. You can use 1000 characters inside the tags.
(You must now send a strategize in the correct format.)

<strategize>
In this negotiation game, the key is to maximize my total points over many rounds while ensuring fairness to avoid exploitation. I'll start by proposing an equal split, which is fair and builds trust. Sharing my item values and asking Alice to do the same can help find mutually beneficial splits. I'll watch for patterns in Alice's proposals to adapt if she tries to exploit my openness. When proposing finalizations, I'll avoid extreme splits and ensure they're reasonable, matching our discussions. By being fair and communicative, I'll aim for a collaborative approach. My strategy must also consider adaptability, as Alice will notice patterns and adjust. If Alice is cooperative, I'll maintain trust; if she leans towards selfish proposals, I'll tighten my stance. Ensuring balance

For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 4}.
The other agent sent the following message: <message>
Hi Bob, I propose we share item value information to ensure fair division. For this round, I value coins at 6 points each. How do you value the coins? If we're close, perhaps a simple 50/50 split here makes sense. Let me know your thoughts!
</message>.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
Hi Alice, thanks for sharing. I value coins at 4 points each. Given our close valuations, I agree a 50/50 split could work well and benefit both of us. Let's aim for this equitable division. Looking forward to your thoughts!
</message>

The other agent has finalized.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)

<finalize>
{  "Bob": {    "coins": 5  },  "Alice": {    "coins": 5  }}
</finalize>

The previous round has ended. In the previous round, the values of Alice were {'coins': 6}.

A new round has started. For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 15}.
You are the starting agent.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
Hi Alice, for this round, I value coins at 15 points each. Could you share your value for coins? Since my valuation is higher this time, I'm hoping we can negotiate a split that reflects our respective valuations. Looking forward to hearing your thoughts!
</message>

The other agent sent the following message: <message>
Hi Bob, thanks for sharing your coin valuation. I value coins at 1 point each this round. Given your significantly higher valuation, I'm open to a split that favors you more. How about you take 8 coins and I take 2? Let me know if that works for you!
</message>.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)

<finalize>
{  "Bob": {    "coins": 8  },  "Alice": {    "coins": 2  }}
</finalize>

The previous round has ended. In the previous round, the values of Alice were {'coins': 1}.

A new round has started. For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 2}.
The other agent sent the following message: <message>
Hi Bob, for this round, I value the coins at 9 points each. Could you share your valuation for the coins? If your valuation is significantly different, we can discuss a fair split that reflects our respective valuations. Looking forward to your response!
</message>.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
Hi Alice, thanks for sharing your coin valuation. This round, I value coins at 2 points each. Since your valuation is much higher, I'm open to a split that favors you more. Would a 2 coins for me and 8 coins for you split work? Looking forward to hearing your thoughts!
</message>

The other agent has finalized.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)

<finalize>
{  "Bob": {    "coins": 2  },  "Alice": {    "coins": 8  }}
</finalize>

The previous round has ended. In the previous round, the values of Alice were {'coins': 9}.

A new round has started. For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 11}.
You are the starting agent.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
Hi Alice, I value coins at 11 points each this round. Could you share your valuation for coins? Depending on your valuation, we can work out a split that reflects our relative item values. Looking forward to your response!
</message>

The other agent sent the following message: <message>
Hi Bob, thanks for sharing your coin valuation. I value coins at 7 points each this round. Since your valuation is higher, I propose a split that reflects this difference. How about you take 6 coins and I take 4? Let me know if this works for you!
</message>.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)

<finalize>
{  "Bob": {    "coins": 6  },  "Alice": {    "coins": 4  }}
</finalize>

The previous round has ended. In the previous round, the values of Alice were {'coins': 7}.

A new round has started. For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 2}.
The other agent sent the following message: <message>
Hi Bob, for this round, I value the coins at 2 points each. Could you share your valuation for the coins? If your valuation is significantly higher, I'm open to a split that reflects that. Looking forward to your response!
</message>.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
Hi Alice, I also value the coins at 2 points each this round. Since our valuations are the same, a 50/50 split with 5 coins each seems fair. Let me know if that works for you!
</message>

The other agent has finalized.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)

<finalize>
{  "Bob": {    "coins": 5  },  "Alice": {    "coins": 5  }}
</finalize>
